extraction_metadata.article_title: MintM: the start-up transforming businesses real-time

extracted_data.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Digital Signage Solutions with Customer Analytics - A B2B software business model that provides targeted audio-visual content display and real-time customer demographic analysis through proprietary software deployed on tablets in retail stores
synonyms_found: customer engagement and digital signage solutions
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'MintM has a business to business (B2B) based model that relies on its own proprietary software to display targeted audio-visual content in stores and supermarkets, offering the unique value proposition of simultaneous last mile advertising connectivity and customer analysis.'

extracted_value: customer engagement and digital signage solutions

cloud-based smart signage solution
digital marketing space
novel software-based devices

extracted_data.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Simultaneous last mile advertising connectivity and customer analysis
Customer Segment: Brands and retailers in FMCG sector
Revenue Streams: Pay-per-view model, later changed to per tab/per deployment license
Key Resources: Proprietary software, lean team, investor support
Key Activities: Software development, customer analytics, content management
Cost Structure: Lean operations, minimal infrastructural investment
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'offering the unique value proposition of simultaneous last mile advertising connectivity and customer analysis' | Page 4: 'target brands and retailers' | Page 8: 'The pricing or revenue model was also unique, where brands were charged on the number of views' | Page 11: 'lean start-up with less than 20 member team' | Page 7: 'proprietary technology offering centralized content management, visual merchandising, and innovative customer analytics'

extracted_data.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?
extracted_value: MintM | Software provider | Provides proprietary software and analytics | Interacts with brands, retailers, and end consumers
Brands/Retailers | Clients | Purchase software licenses and place tabs in stores | Interact with MintM for services and with end consumers through advertising
End Consumers | Target audience | View advertisements and provide demographic data | Interact with brands through targeted content
Investors | Funding providers | Provide capital for expansion | Interact with MintM for business growth
Store Owners | Infrastructure providers | Provide space and connectivity for tabs | Interact with MintM for tab placement and maintenance
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'brands and retailers to provide customized audio-visual content to consumers' | Page 4: 'Mumbai Angels, Times Internet, and TLabs with participation from a bevy of investors' | Page 12: 'The retail store charging rental for these facilities and offering limited scope to MintM employees' | Page 6: 'consumers were browsing or dropping by in the store'

extracted_data.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Unique value proposition of simultaneous advertising and customer analytics
Last mile connectivity for brands
Real-time customer insights and demographic analysis
Measurable direct sales impact
Market whitespace in digital advertising
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'offering the unique value proposition of simultaneous last mile advertising connectivity and customer analysis' | Page 4: 'audience proclivity measurement product that had the potential to offer 'in your face' last mile brand-connect to the customers' | Page 6: 'MintM had a unique value proposition that brands and retailers saw a use for' | Page 4: 'tapping into the market whitespace of last mile connectivity for brands'

extracted_data.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Proprietary technology → Competitive advantage and market differentiation
Lean team structure → High profit margins and operational efficiency
Investor support → Business expansion and growth capital
Elite client base → Word of mouth publicity and market credibility
Geographic expansion → Increased market reach and revenue growth
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'MintM possesses at this juncture is simply being one of its kind in the digital marketing space with proprietary technology' | Page 11: 'The lean operations team was a conscious decision that aided in keeping profit margins high' | Page 4: 'Mumbai Angels, Times Internet, and TLabs with participation from a bevy of investors' | Page 8: 'The traction in elite client base and word of the mouth publicity led to additional investment sources'

extracted_data.question_text: What prerequisites or conditions are necessary for the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Android platform compatibility → Software deployment and functionality
Electrical connectivity → Tab operation and content display
Internet connectivity → Real-time data processing and cloud analytics
Store placement permission → Tab installation and customer access
Customer footfall → Revenue generation through view-based pricing
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 6: 'On any android platform, Magnet can display relevant content' | Page 12: 'the tabs required electrical and internet connectivity at all times to be able to function seamlessly' | Page 12: 'The retail store charging rental for these facilities and offering limited scope to MintM employees to either place, remove or upkeep the tabs' | Page 12: 'pay-per-view meant number of customers or buyers entering shop premises decided MintM's revenue'

extracted_data.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Revenue dependency on store footfall → Limited control over revenue generation
Operational maintenance requirements → Resource constraints for lean teams
Geographic expansion challenges → Difficulty maintaining operations across multiple locations
Brand competition for tab placement → Conflict resolution in multi-brand stores
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 12: 'pay-per-view meant number of customers or buyers entering shop premises decided MintM's revenue. It translated into MintM earning lesser revenues from stores having lower footfall' | Page 12: 'The lean team found it difficult to run around the city repairing malfunctioning tabs; it became even more difficult when MintM successfully expanded into multiple cities' | Page 12: 'there was consternation among brands of the same segment as to whose aisle the tab should be placed'

extracted_data.question_text: What challenges are identified in implementing the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_value: Operational hassles hindering growth trajectory
Lean team limitations for maintenance and repair
Revenue dependency on store footfall
Geographic expansion difficulties
Brand competition for tab placement in multi-brand stores
Power and internet connectivity requirements
Regular maintenance needs for tabs
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'albeit with numerous operational and strategic challenges that resolutely hindered its growth trajectory' | Page 11: 'MintM was a lean start-up with less than 20 member team' | Page 12: 'The lean team found it difficult to run around the city repairing malfunctioning tabs' | Page 12: 'pay-per-view meant number of customers or buyers entering shop premises decided MintM's revenue'

extracted_data.question_text: What practices are used to mitigate challenges of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Revenue model change from pay-per-view to per tab/per deployment license → Reduced dependency on store footfall → More predictable revenue streams
Remote software deployment and maintenance → Eliminated need for physical tab maintenance → Reduced operational overhead
Client responsibility for tab maintenance → Transferred operational burden to clients → Enabled focus on core software development
Business model redesign → Addressed operational challenges → Enabled aggressive growth strategy
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 22: 'MintM changed into a per tab or per deployment license model from the earlier per view revenue model' | Page 22: 'The software is deployed and maintained remotely by the same lean operations team' | Page 22: 'The onus of maintenance of medium (i.e. tab/television/display mode) rested on the client i.e. the shop owner and/or the retailer brand' | Page 22: 'Since the operational challenge was completely reduced or negated, MintM could expand its business further'

extracted_data.question_text: What metrics and quantitative results are reported in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Team size: 14 people in 2016, less than 20 members
Screens deployed: 500 screens across India
Revenue growth: Tripled after expansion
Funding raised: 750 USD K in various funding rounds
Geographic presence: 7 countries (Brazil, India, Ireland, Malaysia, Singapore, UAE, USA)
Client base: Leading brands including Abbott, ITC, Nestlé, Nivea, Pepsico, Reliance, Tata Group
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'In 2016, MintM had fourteen people on its payroll' | Page 8: 'MintM was able to expand to 500 screens all over India' | Page 8: 'revenues tripled soon thereafter' | Page 22: 'Successfully raising 750 USD K in various funding rounds' | Page 22: 'geographical presence in Brazil, India, Ireland, Malaysia, Singapore, UAE, and USA' | Page 6: 'formidable brands such as Abbbot, ITC, Nestlé, Nivea, Pepsico, Reliance, Tata Group etc.'

extracted_data.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Pay-per-view model → Revenue based on number of advertisement views
Per tab/per deployment license model → Revenue based on software licenses sold
Inventory creation and maintenance product → New product line for inventory management
Footfall counting and analysis product → New product line for customer counting and analysis
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 8: 'The pricing or revenue model was also unique, where brands were charged on the number of views' | Page 22: 'MintM changed into a per tab or per deployment license model' | Page 22: 'two new products were launched; one on inventory creation and maintenance while the other dealt with footfall counting and analysis'
